results.title: Dance me to my song
results.creator_credit: Smile Productions, Vertigo Productions, Fandango, Intra Films, Domenico Procacci, Rolf De Heer and Giuseppe Pedersoli
results.brief_description: de Heer’s seventh feature addresses issues of obligation, accountability, need and love, through the conflicted relationship between a severely physically disabled young woman, Julia, and her abusive, short-tempered and lonely carer, Madelaine. Like Heather Rose, the actor inflicted with cerebral palsy that plays her, Julia is confined to a wheelchair and is able to communicate only through a voice-synthesizer. Nevertheless, much to Madelaine’s chagrin, she succeeds in developing a close friendship with Eddie, a man she meets on the street. But Julia wants love and sex, not just companionship, and the two women become locked in a battle for Eddie’s attentions. Rose’s participation in the film, both as its lead and as a co-writer, and the unflinching focus on the minutiae of her labourous and painful daily routine, brings it into the realm of documentary. As in his earlier films ‘Bad Boy Bubby’ and ‘The Quiet Room’, de Heer again focuses on a central character who succeeds in battling against totally inconceivable odds to overcome their victimhood. Cast includes: Heather Rose, Joey Kennedy, John Brumpton, Rena Owen.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Smile Productions, Vertigo Productions, Fandango, Intra Films, Domenico Procacci, Rolf De Heer and Giuseppe Pedersoli

results.title: Dance in the primary school (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Freelance Directors, Schools Council and Derek Monk
results.brief_description: Shows what can be achieved with children of different ages and varying ability and experience. Illustrates the framework of a lesson; some stimuli used to initiate movement - voice, percussion, pictures; how several teachers, drawing on their own resources enrich the children’s experience; ways to extend children in the main part of the lesson; development of a simple group dance.

results.title: Dance in education
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Education and Early Childhood Development
results.brief_description: A program that aims to unify folk dance activities throughout the schools of Victoria by highlighting a series of preparatory exercises, dances by primary school children and more sophisticated dances by ethnic groups.

results.title: Dance frame
results.creator_credit: WNYC-TV (Television station : New York, N.Y.) and Doris Chase
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Dance By Doris Chase”.
The fluid motion of a dancer is circumscribed by rectangular frames of various colours. Accompanied by electronic music by Joan La Barbara and choreographed by Sara Rudner.

group_siblings.title: Dance frame
group_siblings.creator_credit: WNYC-TV (Television station : New York, N.Y.) and Doris Chase

results.title: Dance Dans Tanz Danse
results.brief_description: Founded in 1926 by Marie Rambert, Rambert Dance Company is one of dance’s most consistently innovative and imaginative companies. Here are three modern dances by the company featuring music by Bill Withers. The three are: “Lonely Town, Lonely Street” a jazz ballet which conveys a picture of lonely people in a large city; “Intimate Pages” using Janacek’s Second String Quartet; and “Sergeant Early’s Dream” recalling the folklore of the old world with British, Irish and American folk songs. Rated: G

results.title: Dance crazy in Hollywood
results.creator_credit: RM Arts, Clara Films, Gerard Paquet and Robert Kuperberg
results.brief_description: A collection of cinematic excerpts along with interviews with Hermes Pan, choreographer extraordinaire who created many of the most memorable musical dance moments in the era of the major Hollywood musicals. The film is a biographical study of Pan’s entry into the world of dance, his arrival in Hollywood, and his work with a variety of filmmakers, actors and dancers. Ultimately, it is also a tribute to his contribution to musical film history as the documentary was completed very shortly before his death. Also featuring discussion about and footage of dance greats such as Fred Astaire, Ginger Rogers, Rita Hayworth, Kim Novak, Bob Fosse, Ann Miller, Carol Haney, Elizabeth Taylor, Cyd Charisse and Hermes Pan himself in rare motion picture appearances, the documentary is a personalised insight into the Hollywood musical era with reflective commentary from Pan in the presentation of its archival contents.
